com.supenta.flitchio.sdk

Class FlitchioController

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.supenta.flitchio.sdk.FlitchioController

  • public class FlitchioController
extends Object
    Object providing the main communication channel to the Flitchio Manager app. This is the most important component of the Flitchio SDK, and the only object you have to manipulate in order to use Flitchio with your app.

    The controller initialises and binds to the Flitchio Manager app when you call FlitchioController.onCreate(FlitchioStatusListener). To free the controller properly after use, you must call FlitchioController.onDestroy(). You also need to call FlitchioController.onResume() (or one of its other versions) and FlitchioController.onPause() at the appropriate moments to ensure a clean lifecycle.

    After FlitchioController.onCreate(FlitchioStatusListener) returns, the binding is not effective yet. You will get notified by a FlitchioStatusListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(Status) callback. When the status callback is Status.BOUND, you can start using Flitchio. The FlitchioStatusListener will also notify you about other status changes (like "Flitchio just disconnected"). See FlitchioStatusListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(Status) for details.

    As soon as this controller is in Status.CONNECTED, you can poll data by calling FlitchioController.obtainSnapshot(). You typically call FlitchioController.obtainSnapshot() if you want to use your controller in polling mode, i.e. if your app is designed to have a rendering loop updating the display at high frequency. That's typically the case for games that use a SurfaceView or a GLSurfaceView.

    If you don't want to actively poll data from Flitchio, but rather receive events every time a button has been pressed/released or a joystick has moved, you can use your controller in listening mode. Simply use the variant of FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener) that lets you register a FlitchioEventListener.

    Since:
    0.5.0

        public static FlitchioController getInstance(Context context)
        Get an instance of FlitchioController for this Context.
        Parameters:
        context - The context used to bind. It should be the Activity / Service, not the Application's context.
        Returns:
        An instance of FlitchioController.
        Since:
        0.5.0

        Get an Intent to download the FlitchioManager app on the Play Store.
        Returns:
        An intent to open the PlayStore on FlitchioManager page.
        Since:

      • getVersionCode

        public static int getVersionCode()
        Get the SDK version code used in the JAR. This returns the "android:versionCode" value defined in the Manifest.
        Returns:
        The version code of the SDK.
        Since:
        0.5.0

      • getFlitchioManagerVersionCode

        public static int getFlitchioManagerVersionCode(Context context)
        Get the version code of FlitchioManager installed on the system. This corresponds to the "android:versionCode" attribute in the Manifest of Flitchio Manager.
        Returns:
        The version code of Flitchio Manager, or -1 if it not installed.
        Since:
        0.5.0

      • onCreate

        public void onCreate(FlitchioStatusListener statusListener)
        Initialise this controller.

        You must call this method appropriately in the lifecycle of your Activity or Service. It should be called in the onCreate() method of your Activity / Service.

        This method attempts to initialise the controller and bind to Flitchio. At the moment it returns, the binding is not yet effective. To be notified with the status changes (binding effective or failed, Flitchio connected or disconnected), implement a FlitchioStatusListener and pass it. See FlitchioStatusListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(Status) for the status changes you can watch.

        In the rare case that you don't wish to receive status callbacks, you can pass null.

        Parameters:
        statusListener - The listener for status changes.
        Since:
        0.7.0

      • onResume

        public void onResume(FlitchioEventListener eventListener,
                     Handler handler)
        Resume this controller.

        You must call this method (or one of its other versions) appropriately in the lifecycle of your Activity or Service. If you use this controller in an Activity, this method should be called in your Activity's onResume(). If you use this controller in a Service, this method can be called right after FlitchioController.onCreate(FlitchioStatusListener).

        After calling this method, you are ensured to receive at least one FlitchioStatusListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(Status) callback with the current status.

        This is a variant of FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener) that allows you to define the thread on which you wish to receive the event callbacks.

        Parameters:
        eventListener - The event listener.
        handler - The handler associated to the thread on which the callbacks will happen.
        Since:
        0.7.0
        See Also:
        FlitchioController.onResume(), FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener)

      • onResume

        public void onResume(FlitchioEventListener eventListener)
        Resume this controller.

        You must call this method (or one of its other versions) appropriately in the lifecycle of your Activity or Service. If you use this controller in an Activity, this method should be called in your Activity's onResume(). If you use this controller in a Service, this method can be called right after FlitchioController.onCreate(FlitchioStatusListener).

        After calling this method, you are ensured to receive at least one FlitchioStatusListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(Status) callback with the current status.

        This is a variant of FlitchioController.onResume() that allows you to listen for button and joystick events. You will get these event callback an arbitrary thread (different from the main thread). If you want to receive event callbacks on the main thread, use FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener, Handler) instead, with a handler associated with the main thread.

        Parameters:
        eventListener - The event listener.
        Since:
        0.7.0
        See Also:
        FlitchioController.onResume(), FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener, Handler)

      • onResume

        public void onResume()
        Resume this controller.

        You must call this method (or one of its other versions) appropriately in the lifecycle of your Activity or Service. If you use this controller in an Activity, this method should be called in your Activity's onResume(). If you use this controller in a Service, this method can be called right after FlitchioController.onCreate(FlitchioStatusListener).

        After calling this method, you are ensured to receive at least one FlitchioStatusListener.onFlitchioStatusChanged(Status) callback with the current status.

        This variant only enables you to follow status changes of Flitchio. If you also wish to listen to button and joystick events, use FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener) instead.

        Since:
        0.7.0
        See Also:
        FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener), FlitchioController.onResume(FlitchioEventListener, Handler)

      • onPause

        public void onPause()
        Pause this controller.

        You must call this method appropriately in the lifecycle of your Activity or Service. If you use this controller in an Activity, this method should be called in your Activity's onPause(). If you use this controller in a Service, this method can be called right before FlitchioController.onDestroy().

        Since:
        0.5.0

      • onDestroy

        public void onDestroy()
        Terminate this controller.

        You must call this method appropriately in the lifecycle of your Activity or Service. It should be called in the onDestroy() method of your Activity / Service.

        Since:
        0.5.0

      • obtainSnapshot

        public FlitchioSnapshot obtainSnapshot()
        Retrieve the latest state of Flitchio as a FlitchioSnapshot. Note: before the status is Status.CONNECTED, the snapshot returned by this method is always empty.
        Returns:
        The snapshot representing the latest state of Flitchio. It is never null: when the status isn't Status.DISCONNECTED, you get an empty snapshot instead.
        Since:
        0.5.0

      • getStatus

        public Status getStatus()
        Retrieve the current status of this controller. To get notified of status changes, pass a FlitchioStatusListener in FlitchioController.onCreate(FlitchioStatusListener).
        Returns:
        The status of this controller.
        Since:
        0.7.0
